qas.question: Who did Burke want constitutional limits on the power of?
What type of institution did Burke think could offer opposition to abuses of power?
What type of group were the "king's friends"?
What was Burke's most important publication about limiting royal power?

answers.text: Thoughts on the Cause of the Present Discontents of 23 April 1770

qas.question: Who wanted to limit the powers of the political parties?

plausible_answers.text: Thoughts on the Cause of the Present Discontents

qas.question: What was the name of the paper the neo-Tories published?
When did Burke take the leading role in the debate?
What party did Burke believe would have strong principles?
What were Burke and his friends nicknamed?

context: <b4_0>Burke<b4_0/> took a leading role in the debate regarding the constitutional limits to the executive authority of <a0_0>the king<a0_0/>. He argued strongly against unrestrained royal power and for the role of <a1_0>political parties<a1_0/> in maintaining a principled opposition capable of preventing abuses, either by the monarch, or by specific factions within the government. His most important publication in this regard was his <a3_0><b5_0>Thoughts on the Cause of the Present Discontents<b5_0/> of <b6_0>23 April 1770<b6_0/><a3_0/>. Burke identified the "discontents" as stemming from the "secret influence" of <b7_0>a <a2_0>neo-Tory<a2_0/> group<b7_0/> he labelled as, the "<b8_0>king's friends<b8_0/>", whose system "comprehending the exterior and interior administrations, is commonly called, in the technical language of the Court, Double Cabinet". Britain needed a party with "an unshaken adherence to principle, and attachment to connexion, against every allurement of interest". Party divisions "whether operating for good or evil, are things inseparable from free government".
